Reef Shark.fact: Reef sharks are known for their agility and speed.

Hammerhead.fact: Hammerheads use their wide-set eyes to scan for prey.

Mollisquama parini.fact: The species was identified based on five features not seen in the 1979 specimen.

Mollisquama mississippiensis.fact: Pocket sharks have fewer vertebrae and numerous light-producing photophores that cover much of the body.

Great White.fact: The great white can detect a drop of blood from miles away.

Lantern Shark.fact: Their glowing bodies help them hide, warn predators, or communicate with other lantern sharks.

Sand Devil.fact: An ambush predator that buries itself in sand or mud and waits for prey to pass overhead.

Creek Whaler.fact: A stocky, spindle-shaped requiem shark endemic to northern Australia.

Crying Izak.fact: A deepwater catshark found in Kenya and Tanzania. Conservation status: Data Deficient.

Frog Shark.fact: A very rare deepwater species from the sleeper shark family Somniosidae.

Crocodile Shark.fact: Snaps its powerful jaws when out of waterâ€”earning its crocodilian name.

Little Sleeper Shark.fact: A slow-swimming, low-activity species that mainly preys on squid.

Starry Catshark.fact: Colorful with milky white blotches and rusty brown spots and patches.

Small-eye Hammerhead.fact: Has a golden hue from eating shrimp and catfish. A small species of hammerhead.

Scalloped Hammerhead.fact: Endangered and widely caught for meat and fins due to high fin ray count.

Nervous Shark.fact: Skittish and timid. Harmless to humans, it mostly eats small fish, crabs, and sea snakes.

Megalodon.fact: The Megalodon was one of the largest predators ever.

Shiny Shark.fact: A mysterious rare variant that glimmers in the moonlight.

Great Hammerhead Shark.fact: The shark feeds mostly at dusk and has been seen using its hammer-shaped head to bludgeon and pin stingrays before biting them.

Grey Reef Shark.fact: Inquisitive and sometimes bold around divers, but usually retreats once curiosity is satisfied.

Lemon Shark.fact: Nocturnal and active near docks, saltwater creeks, estuaries, bays, and inlets.

Leopard Shark.fact: Commercially fished but now well-managed in the U.S.; Mexican population status is unknown.

Oceanic Whitetip Shark.fact: Known for persistent behavior around divers and implicated in unprovoked attacks.

Pacific Sharpnose Shark.fact: A small shark with adults reaching only around 2.3 ft; matures quickly.

Pyjama Shark.fact: Small, striped shark with nasal barbels and far-back dorsal fins; easily identified by its pajamas-like appearance.

Sand Tiger Shark.fact: Generally placid despite a fierce appearance. If approached too closely, it thumps its tail, producing a loud booming sound.

Scalloped Hammerhead Shark.fact: Forms massive schools, making them highly vulnerable to fishing. Endangered globally.

Sharptooth Lemon Shark.fact: Usually sluggish and shy, but can be aggressive if provoked. Swims slowly near the sea floor.

Blacknose Shark.fact: Pups may mature around age 2. These sharks breed in alternate years, and live for approximately 10 years.

Blacktip Reef Shark.fact: On flood tide swarms of blacktip reef sharks move over shallow reef flats. They are often seen swimming in calf-deep water with the tips of their dorsal fins breaking the surface.

Blacktip Shark.fact: This is an active shark and is often seen spinning and leaping above the surface. The shark migrates to deeper water in winter.

Blue Shark.fact: This shark has a dark blue back, bright blue flanks and sharp demarcation to a white underside. They are highly migratory with complex movements related to prey availability and reproductive cycles.

Brown Shyshark.fact: The shark prefers to be inshore on the continental shelf, often in shallow, sandy areas, or the rocky bottom from 0 to 114.8 ft [0 to 35 m].

Bull Shark.fact: A danger to humans â€“ due to its size, dentition and aggressiveness, it is regarded as one of the most dangerous tropical sharks.

Caribbean Reef Shark.fact: Teeth in both jaws are serrated. Teeth of the upper jaw have narrow cusps and broad bases; lower jaw teeth are narrow, erect with triangular cusps.

Bronze Whaler Shark.fact: Often seen close inshore feeding on schooling fish, frequently within the surf zone. Also found around offshore islands to depths of 100 m.

Dusky Shark.fact: Migratory in temperate and subtropical areas of the Pacific and Atlantic. Young sharks form feeding aggregations.

Galapagos Shark.fact: This shark may make a threat display with arched back and twisting motion. An attack may follow.

Silky Shark.fact: No description provided â€” a sleek, open-ocean species known for its smooth texture and speed.

Silvertip Shark.fact: Large, bold, and potentially dangerous. Vulnerable due to slow growth and targeted fishing in remote populations.

Smooth Hammerhead.fact: Near-threatened and sometimes confused with scalloped hammerheads in tropical waters.

Smoothhound.fact: Used for food and fishmeal; also caught by sport fishers and sometimes kept in aquaria.

Spinner Shark.fact: An active schooling shark known for feeding runs that end with spinning leaps out of the water.

Tiger Shark.fact: Omnivorous and opportunistic; known to eat everything from turtles and fish to garbage and sea snakes.

Horn Shark.fact: Solitary and slow-moving, feeds on hard-shelled mollusks, crustaceans, and small fish.

Bluntnose Sixgill Shark.fact: Sluggish but strong, nocturnal, and highly sensitive to light. Prefers deep waters.

Broadnose Sevengill Shark.fact: Active and strong, often found inshore at high tide and cruising near the bottom or surface.

Frilled Shark.fact: Bycatch in deep-sea fisheries; swims with its mouth open in captivity, possibly to lure prey with its white teeth.

Sharpnose Sevengill Shark.fact: Near-threatened and poorly understood. Likely strong swimmers and will bite when captured. Notable for five rows of comb-shaped lower teeth.

Basking Shark.fact: Highly migratory filter-feeder, often seen feeding on plankton with mouth open. Can leap from the water and engage in complex courtship.

Bigeye Thresher Shark.fact: Identified by its massive whip-like tail, sometimes as long as its body. One of three thresher shark species.

Crocodile Shark.fact: Ovoviviparous; pups may feed on unfertilized eggs and possibly cannibalize siblings before birth.

Goblin Shark.fact: Has a blade-like snout and extendable jaws that rapidly shoot forward to catch prey. Teeth suggest a diet of fish and squid.

Longfin Mako Shark.fact: Has long pectoral fins and a less pointed snout than the shortfin mako. Sleek and powerful swimmer.

Megamouth Shark.fact: Unmistakable for its huge head and massive terminal mouth. Exceptionally rare and deep-dwelling.

Porbeagle Shark.fact: Migratory and critically endangered in parts of the Atlantic. Moves inshore in summer and offshore in winter.

Salmon Shark.fact: Seasonally migratory, following prey. Adults migrate further north than young and segregate by age and sex.

Shortfin Mako Shark.fact: The fastest shark in the sea, known for spectacular leaps and high activity.

White Shark.fact: A super-predator: intelligent, curious, and inspects objects with its teeth due to lack of hands. Arguably the most formidable shark.

Bluegrey Carpet Shark.fact: Prefers shallow inshore waters, staying close to the ocean floor at depths under 6 meters.

Epaulette Shark.fact: Known to survive in tide pools and coral reefs, sometimes walking between pools with their fins.

Nurse Shark.fact: Often rests in big snuggly piles of 2 to 30 individuals and sticks to the same home range.

Spotted Wobbegong.fact: Nocturnal ambush predator that prowls reefs at night and crawls using its fins.

Tawny Nurse Shark.fact: Docile but reactive when caught; popular with divers and known to â€˜spitâ€™ water when distressed.

Whale Shark.fact: The gentle giant of the sea; massive, placid, and highly vulnerable to exploitation. Doesnâ€™t thrive in captivity.

Whitespotted Bamboo Shark.fact: Nocturnal and secretive, spending its days hidden in reef crevices before emerging to hunt.

Zebra Shark.fact: Often rests facing the current, propped on fins. More active at night.

Bahamas Sawshark.fact: Found in the Northwest Atlantic, especially between Florida, Cuba, and the Bahamas. Recognized by its saw-like snout.

Angel Shark.fact: Historically found in the Northeast Atlantic and Mediterranean, but now vanished from many regions.

Bramble Shark.fact: Little is known about their behavior, though they are thought to be sluggish and deep-sea dwellers.

Cookiecutter Shark.fact: Poor swimmers, likely migrate vertically. Named for their circular bites taken out of larger animals.

Great Lanternshark.fact: Found in deep waters of the Northwest and Northeast Atlantic. Likely bioluminescent.

Greenland Shark.fact: One of the longest-living vertebrates, can reach lengths over 21 ft and live for centuries.

Gulper Shark.fact: Critically endangered in parts of Australia. Targeted for liver oil and meat in deep-sea fisheries.

Kitefin Shark.fact: Deepwater shark with slow growth and large size potential. Matures at 2.5 to 5.2 ft.

Pacific Sleeper Shark.fact: Deep-dwelling shark with unique teeth â€” spear-like uppers and slicing lower teeth.

Pygmy Shark.fact: Possibly the smallest shark alive. Cylindrical body with glowing belly and large eyes.

Spiny Dogfish.fact: Exceptionally long-lived and slow-growing. Can live over 75 years and matures late.
